13  *THE INSURANCE ACT, 1938 
ACT NO. 4 OF 19381 
[26th February , 1938.]  
 
An Act to consolidate and amend the law relating to the business of insurance.  
 
WHEREAS it is expedient to consolidate and amend the law relating to the business of insurance ; It is 
hereby enacted as follows: — 
PART I 
PRELIMINARY  
1. Short title, extent and commencement. — (1) This Act may be called the Insurance  Act,1938.  
 
2[(2) It extends to the whole of India 3***.]  
 
(3) It shall come into force on such date4as the Central Government may, by notification in the 
Official Gazette, appoint in this  behalf.  
2. Definitions. — In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or  context, — 
 
5[(1) “actuary” means an actuary as defined in clause ( a) of sub -section ( 1) of section 2 of the 
Actuaries Act, 2006 (35 of 2006);  
(1A) “Authority” means the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India established 
under sub -section ( 1) of section 3 of the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority Act, 1999 
(41 of  1999);]  
6[(2) “policy -holder” includes a person to whom the whole of the interest of the policy -holder in 
the policy is assigned onc e and for all, but does not include an assignee thereof whose interest in the 
policy is defeasible or is for the time being subject to any condition ;]  
7[(3) “approved securities” means — 
 
(i) Government securities and other securities charged on the revenues o f the Central 
Government or of the Government of a 8*** State or guaranteed fully as regards principal and 
interest by the Central Government, or the Government of any 8*** State  ; 
 
 
1. The Act has been extended to — 
Goa, Daman and Diu with modifications by Reg. 12 of 1962, s. 3 and the Schedule; and came into force in Pondicherry on 1 - 
10-1963, vide Reg. 7 of 1963, s. 3 and the Schedule I; and brought into force in Dadra and Nagar Haveli (w.e.f. 1 -7-1965) by 
Reg. 6 of  1963, s. 2 and the Schedule I; the whole of the Union territory of Lakshadweep (w.e.f. 1 -10-1967) vide Reg. 8 of 1965, 
s. 3 and the Schedule; and brought into force in the State of Sikkim (w.e.f. 1 -7-1975) vide S.O. 274( E), dated 24 -6-1975.  
2. Subs. by Ac t 47 of 1950, s. 2, for sub -section ( 2) (w.e.f. 1 -6-1950).  
3. The words  “except the  State  of Jammu and Kashmir” omitted  by Act 62 of 1956,  s. 2 and the Schedule  (w.e.f.  1-11-1956).  
4. 1st July, 1939: see notification no. 589 -(4)/38, dated the 1st April, 1939, Gazette of India, 1939, Pt. I, p.  631. 
5. Subs. by Act 5 of 2015, s. 3, for clauses ( 1) and ( 1A) (w.e.f.26 -12-2014).  
6. Subs. by Act 6 of 1946, s. 2, for clause ( 2) (w.e.f.20 -3-1946).

itself, be made by an endorsement on the policy communicated to the insurer and registered by him in the

shall affect the rights of the nominee only to the extent of the interest of the transferee or assignee, as the 
case may  be, in the  policy:

or assignment, the same nomination shall stand automatically revived when the policy is reassigned by the 
assignee or retransferred b y the transferee in favour of the policyholder on repayment of loan other than on

(a) require from an insurer such information, certified if so required by an auditor or actuary, as it

(b) require an insurer to submit for its examination at the principal place of business of the insurer 
in India, any books of account, register or other document, or to supply any statement which may be

(c) examine any officer of an insurer on oath, in relation to any such information, book, register,

SPECIAL PROVISIONS OF LAW  
45. Policy not be called in question on ground of misstatement after three years. —(1) No policy 
of life insurance shall be called in question on any ground whatsoever after the expiry of three years from 
the date of the policy, i.e., from the date of issuance of the policy or the date of commencement of risk or 
the date of revival of the policy or the date of the rider to the policy,  whichever  islater.  
(2) A policy of life insurance may be called in question at any time within three years from the date of 
issuance of the policy or the date of commencement of risk or the date of revival of the policy or the date 
of the rider to the policy,  whichever is later, on the ground of  fraud:  
Provided that the insurer shall have to communicate in writing to the insured or the legal representatives 
or nominees or assignees of the insured the grounds and materials on which such decision is based.  
Explanation I. —For the purposes of this sub -section, the expression “fraud” means any of the 
following acts committed by the insured or by his agent, with intent to deceive the insurer or to induce the 
insurer to issue a life insurance policy: — 
(a) the sugge stion, as a fact of that which is not true and which the insured does not believe to be 
true; 
(b) the active concealment of a fact by the insured having knowledge or belief of  thefact;  
(c) any other act fitted to deceive;  and 
(d) any such act or omission as the law sp ecially declares to be  fraudulent.  
Explanation II . —Mere silence as to facts likely to affect the assessment of the risk by the insurer is not 
fraud, unless the circumstances of the case are such that regard being had to them, it is the duty of the 
insured  or his agent keeping silence, to speak, or unless his silence is, in itself, equivalent to speak.

__data__.text: The Insurance Act, 1938 is an Act that incorporates all amendments including the amendment by the Insurance (Amendment) Act, 2021. It outlines the regulations and restrictions for insurers, including registration, capital requirements, investment, loans and management, investigation, appointment of staff, control over management, amalgamation and transfer of insurance business, assignment or transfer of policies and nominations, commission and rebates, licensing of agents, management by administrator, acquisition of the undertakings of insurers in certain cases, life insurance council and general insurance council and committees thereof, tariff advisory committee and control of tariff rates, solvency margin, advance payment of premium and restrictions on the opening of a new place of business, and provident societies. It also outlines special provisions relating to external companies, re-insurance with Indian re-insurers, and an advisory committee.

The Insurance Act, 1938 is an Act to consolidate and amend the law relating to the business of insurance. It applies to the whole of India and came into force on a date appointed by the Central Government. The Act defines various terms such as "insurer", "policy", "Government security", "auditor", "fire insurance business", "general insurance business", "health insurance business", "Indian insurance company", and "marine insurance business". It also outlines the penalties for default in complying with the Act, carrying on insurance business in contravention of sections, and wrongfully obtaining or withholding property. The Act also outlines the powers of the Court to order restoration of property of insurer or compensation in certain cases, the power of the Central Government to make rules, and the power of the Authority to make regulations.

The Insurance Act, 1938, incorporates all amendments till 2021 and outlines the regulations for insurance companies in India. No person shall take out or renew any policy of insurance in respect of any property in India or any ship or other vessel or aircraft registered in India with an insurer whose principal place of business is outside India save with the prior permission of the Authority. Insurers must be subject to all the provisions of the Act in relation to any class of insurance business so long as their liabilities in India remain unsatisfied. The Authority may register an applicant as an insurer and grant them a certificate of registration if they meet certain criteria. The Authority may also suspend or cancel any registration and issue a duplicate certificate of registration. Insurers must not use a name that is identical or similar to an existing insurer without consent from the Authority. Insurers carrying on the business of life insurance, general insurance, health insurance or re-insurance in India must have a paid-up equity capital of at least one hundred crore.

This section of the Insurance Act, 1938, outlines the voting rights of shareholders in public companies that carry out life insurance, general and health insurance, and re-insurance business. It states that the voting rights of shareholders must be proportionate to the paid-up amount of the equity shares held by them. It also outlines the requirements for making a declaration of interest in a share held in the name of another person. It further outlines the requirements for the separation of accounts and funds for different classes of insurance business, as well as the audit and actuarial report and abstract that must be conducted annually.

The Insurance Act, 1938 requires insurers to maintain records of policies, claims, and transfers, as well as to issue policies above a specified threshold in electronic form. The Authority has the power to order revaluation and to inspect returns. Insurers must invest and keep invested assets equivalent to the sum of their liabilities to policyholders in India, less unpaid premiums and loans granted on policies. Investments must be held in Government securities, other approved securities, and approved investments. The Authority can direct insurers to realise unsuitable investments. Funds must be held free of any encumbrance, charge, hypothecation, or lien.

The Insurance Act, 1938, incorporates all amendments till 2021-08-12. Section 27D outlines the manner and conditions of investment of assets to be held by an insurer for the purposes of the Act. Section 27E prohibits investment of funds outside India. Section 30 outlines the liability of directors, etc., for loss due to contravention of section 27, 27A, 27B, 27C, 27D or section 29. Section 32B outlines the obligations of insurers in respect of rural or unorganised sector and backward classes, and Section 32C outlines the obligations of insurers in respect of insurance business in third party risks of motor vehicles. Section 34 outlines the power of the Authority to issue directions to insurers generally or to any insurer in particular.

The Insurance Act, 1938 incorporates all amendments till 2021-08-12. Subs. by Act 41 of 1999, s. 30 and the First Schedule, for “Controller” (w.e.f. 19 -4-2000). Subs. by Act 5 of 2015, s. 38, for sub -section ( 4) (w.e.f. 26 -12-2014). The Act provides the 1[Authority] with the power to remove managerial persons from office, appoint additional directors, and issue directions regarding re-insurance treaties. It also provides the 1[Authority] with the power to enter and search any building or place where books, accounts, or other documents relating to any claim, rebate, or commission are kept. The Act also provides for the submission of balance sheets, actuarial reports, abstracts, and other reports to the 3[Authority] in order to approve any amalgamation or transfer.

The Insurance Act, 1938 is an act that incorporates all amendments till 2021-08-12. It outlines the process of amalgamation or transfer of one insurer's business to another. It requires a declaration signed by all parties involved, balance sheets, and other reports to be submitted to the Authority. It also outlines the power of the Authority to prepare a scheme of amalgamation, the transfer of properties and assets, and the payment of compensation to employees. It also outlines the process of nomination by a policyholder, including the delivery of notice to the insurer, the priority of claims, and the beneficial entitlement of nominees.

The Insurance Act, 1938, incorporates all amendments till 2021-08-12. Section 40A limits the expenditure on commission, while Section 40B and 40C limit the expenses of management in life insurance and general, health insurance and re-insurance business respectively. Section 41 prohibits the allowance or offering of rebates as an inducement to take out or renew an insurance policy. Section 42D outlines the process for issuing a registration to act as an intermediary or insurance intermediary. Section 43 requires insurers and persons acting on their behalf to maintain a record of insurance agents. Section 44A gives the Authority the power to call for information to ensure compliance with Sections 40, 40B and 40C. Section 44 outlines the prohibition of cessation of payments of commission. Section 51 outlines the process for repudiating a life insurance policy on the ground of fraud.

Section 48A of the Insurance Act, 1938 states that no insurance agent, intermediary, or insurance intermediary shall be eligible to be or remain a director in an insurance company. Section 48B further states that an insurer specified in sub-clause (b) of clause (9) of section 2 and carrying on life insurance business shall not have a common director with another such insurer. Section 50 states that an insurer shall give notice to the policy-holder informing them of the options available to them on the lapsing of a policy, unless these are set forth in the policy. Section 52G provides protection of action taken under sections 52A to 52D, and Section 52F states that any director or officer of the insurer or any other person who fails to deliver to the Administrator any books of account, registers or any other documents, in his custody relating to the business of the insurer, or retains any property of such insurer, shall be liable to penalty. Finally, Section 68 states that the National Company Law Tribunal may order the winding up of an insurance company if certain conditions are met.

This section of the Insurance Act, 1938, outlines the procedures for the winding up of insurance companies and the calculation of policy values in the event of liquidation or insolvency. It also outlines the power of the Central Government to impose reciprocal disabilities on non-Indian companies, and the incorporation of the Insurance Association of India. It also outlines the formation of the Life Insurance Council and General Insurance Council, and the Executive Committees of each. The Executive Committees are made up of representatives of members of the Council, an eminent person not connected with insurance business, and representatives of insurance agents, third party administrators, surveyors, and policyholders. The Authority may nominate persons to fill any vacancies. Each Executive Committee may make bye-laws for the regulation of their proceedings.

This section of the Insurance Act, 1938 outlines the functions of the Executive Committees of the Life Insurance Council and the General Insurance Council. It also outlines the powers of the Central Government to remove difficulties, the establishment of the Tariff Advisory Committee, the composition of the Advisory Committee, the power to make rules in respect of matters in this Part, the surveyors or loss assessors, the sufficiency of assets, and the requirements for groups of insurers. The Executive Committees are responsible for aiding, advising, and assisting insurers in setting up standards of conduct and sound practice, rendering advice to the Authority in controlling the expenses of insurers, and bringing to the Authority's attention any insurer acting in a manner prejudicial to the interests of policy holders. The Tariff Advisory Committee is responsible for regulating rates of insurance, and the Authority is responsible for preparing a scheme for the existing employees of the Tariff Advisory Committee on its dissolution. Surveyors or loss assessors must possess certain academic qualifications and be a member of a professional body of surveyors and loss assessors. Insurers must maintain an excess of value of assets over the amount of liabilities of not less than fifty percent of the amount of minimum capital. Groups of insurers must comply with certain requirements.

This section of the Insurance Act, 1938, outlines the regulations and restrictions for insurance companies in India. It includes provisions for solvency margins, premiums, re-insurance, registration, winding up, and penalties for non-compliance. It also outlines the powers of the Authority, the Advisory Committee, and the Adjudicating Officer. Penalties for non-compliance range from fines to imprisonment.

The Insurance Act, 1938 incorporates all amendments till 2021-08-12. Section 91 explains that a person shall be deemed to be a nominee of a delinquent if they possess or may be required to exercise any right or power which enables the delinquent to exercise control over the company's affairs. Section 92 states that any claim to any property attached under this section or any objection to such attachment shall be made by an application to the court. Section 107A states that the Chairman, etc. to be public servant is omitted. Section 108 states that the court shall make such order as it thinks fit respecting the disposal of any such property for the purpose of effectually enforcing any liability under this section. Section 110A states that the delegation of powers and duties of the Chairperson of the Authority shall be such as may be prescribed. Section 110F states that the provisions of sections 3, 3A, 27B, 28B, 33, 34 clause (a) of sections 34E, 34F, 40C, 44A, 64U to 64UM (both inclusive), 64V, 64VA, 64VB, 64VC, and 101A, 101C, 110D, 110G and 110H shall apply to the general insurance business carried on by a State Government or a Government company. Section 114 states that the Central Government may make rules to carry out the purposes of this Act, including the conditions and manner of foreign investment, the manner in which it shall be determined which of the transactions of an insurer are to be deemed for the purposes of this Act to be insurance business, the form of any account, return or register required by the Part III and the manner in which such account, return or register shall be verified, the conditions and the matters which may be prescribed under sub-sections (5), (6), (10) and (12) of section 92, the manner of inquiry under sub-section (1) of section 105C, the form in which an appeal may be preferred under sub-section (2) and the fee payable in respect of such appeal and the procedure for filing and disposing of an appeal under sub-section (6) of section 110, and any other matter which is to be or may be prescribed.

The Insurance Act, 1938, incorporates all amendments till 2021-08-12. It outlines the obligations of insurers in respect of rural or social or unorganized sector and backward classes, the minimum percentage of insurance business in third party risks of motor vehicles, the minimum information to be maintained by insurers or intermediary or insurance intermediary, the form in which balance-sheets in respect of the insurance business of each of the insurers concerned and the manner in which actuarial reports and abstracts in respect of the life insurance business are to be prepared, the manner of assessment of compensation, the fee to be charged by the insurer, the manner and amount of remuneration or reward to be paid or received by way of commission or otherwise to an insurance agent or an intermediary or insurance intermediary, the requisite qualifications or practical training or examination to be passed for appointment as an insurance agent, the code of conduct, the manner and the fees for issue of a licence, the code of conduct, the fee for issue of duplicate licence, the requirements of capital, form of business and other conditions to act as an intermediary or insurance intermediary, the form of balance-sheet, the norms for surrender value of life insurance policy, the manner of exclusion of certain assets, the manner of valuation of liabilities, the period for which a person may act as a surveyor or loss assessor, the manner of receipt of premium, the matters relating to re-insurance, the powers of the Authority not to apply to International Financial Services Centre, and the exemptions from any of the provisions of this Act.

The Insurance Act, 1938 is an Act to consolidate and amend the law relating to the business of insurance in India. It incorporates all amendments till 2021-08-12 and outlines the regulations for insurance companies, including registration, capital requirements, investment, loans and management, investigation, appointment of staff, control over management, amalgamation and transfer of insurance business, assignment or transfer of policies and nominations, commission and rebates, licensing of agents, management by administrator, acquisition of the undertakings of insurers in certain cases, life insurance council and general insurance council and committees thereof, tariff advisory committee and control of tariff rates, solvency margin, advance payment of premium and restrictions on the opening of a new place of business, and provident societies. It also outlines the voting rights of shareholders in public companies, the requirements for making a declaration of interest in a share held in the name of another person, the requirements for the separation of accounts and funds for different classes of insurance business, the audit and actuarial report and abstract that must be conducted annually, the power of the Authority to order revaluation and to inspect returns, the power of the Authority to make rules and regulations, the power of the Authority to remove managerial persons from office, appoint additional directors, and issue directions regarding re-insurance treaties, the power of the Authority to enter and search any building or place where books, accounts, or other documents relating to any claim, rebate, or commission are kept, the prohibition of cessation of payments of commission, the prohibition of offering of rebates as an inducement to take out or renew an insurance policy, the process for issuing a registration to act as an intermediary or insurance intermediary, the process for repudiating a life insurance policy on the ground of fraud, the prohibition of insurance agents, intermediaries, or insurance intermediaries to be or remain a director in an insurance company, the requirement to give notice to the policy-holder informing them of the options available to them on the lapsing of a policy, and the power of the National Company Law Tribunal to order the winding up of an insurance company.

The Insurance Act, 1938 outlines the regulations and restrictions for insurance companies in India. It includes provisions for solvency margins, premiums, re-insurance, registration, winding up, and penalties for non-compliance. It also outlines the powers of the Authority, the Advisory Committee, and the Adjudicating Officer. Penalties for non-compliance range from fines to imprisonment. The Act outlines the procedures for the winding up of insurance companies and the calculation of policy values in the event of liquidation or insolvency. It also outlines the power of the Central Government to impose reciprocal disabilities on non-Indian companies, and the incorporation of the Insurance Association of India. It also outlines the formation of the Life Insurance Council and General Insurance Council, and the Executive Committees of each. The Executive Committees are responsible for aiding, advising, and assisting insurers in setting up standards of conduct and sound practice, rendering advice to the Authority in controlling the expenses of insurers, and bringing to the Authority's attention any insurer acting in a manner prejudicial to the interests of policy holders. The Tariff Advisory Committee is responsible for regulating rates of insurance, and the Authority is responsible for preparing a scheme for the existing employees of the Tariff Advisory Committee on its dissolution. The Act also outlines the obligations of insurers in respect of rural or social or unorganized sector and backward classes, the minimum percentage of insurance business in third party risks of motor vehicles, the minimum information to be maintained by insurers or intermediary or insurance intermediary, the form of any account, return or register required by the Part III and the manner in which such account, return or register shall be verified, the conditions and the matters which may be prescribed under sub-sections (5), (6), (10) and (12) of section 92, the manner of inquiry under sub-section (1) of section 105C, the form in which an appeal may be preferred under sub-section (2) and the fee payable in respect of such appeal and the procedure for filing and disposing of an appeal under sub-section (6) of section 110, and any other matter which is to be or may be prescribed.
